posts.author: Go-Button
posts.post_text: September 20, 2015 at 12:53 AM#13The sequence pool is normally not made for playback cues. Its mainly to organize your show and have a backup if you need an already deleted executor back. Of course you can playback directly out of this pool, but I think it is more complicated. I haven't did what you've request before. I hope there is an easy solution but actually I'm not sure.

posts.author: Go-Button
posts.post_text: September 22, 2015 at 10:01 AM#14I have tried different commands but haven't found an easy solution.What speaks against assigning all sequences to virtual executors?Use the command: Assign Sequence x Thru y at Executor a.b Thru a.cThis will assign all sequences at once, but single, to multiple executors.This could look like in the attached photo. So you can use the advantages of the normal playback control and additionally you can select an run as much cues you like together.I know that this is not exactly what you've requested but could be an easy solution. posts.post_text: September 24, 2015 at 12:52 PM#17you could operate the operationof set.time fader via a macroe.g. to fade in all your sequences in 3 seconds, macro could go something like this (not tested)prepare for common go:CodeSpecialmaster *."exec time" At 0 [follow]ManualXfade On Specialmaster *."exec time" [go]push sequence tiles in a poolplaybackmode enabled sequence poolcontinue macro to fade inn all sequences:CodeSpecialmaster *."exec time" At [color=#CC3300][b]10[/b][/color] Time 3   [wait 3.1]ManualXfade Off Specialmaster *."exec time" [follow]Specialmaster *."exec time" At 0[color=#FF0000]* Assumes 10 seconds is default/max set-time range[/color]
